conclusion: Two cars, A and B, moving on a straight lane with velocities over time plotted on a graph.
Car A's graph has two identical arcs, and Car B's graph is a straight line.
The x-axis is time in seconds, and the y-axis is velocity in meters per second.
Car A's velocity starts at 0 m/s and increases to about 2 m/s over 4 seconds, following a curved path.
The slope of the line represents acceleration, so Car A's acceleration isn't constant.
Car A's graph starts at 0 m/s at time 0, rises to about 1 m/s at 2 seconds, and then to about 2 m/s at 4 seconds.
Two identical arcs mean the shape of the curve from 0 to 2 seconds is the same as from 2 to 4 seconds.
From 0 to 2 seconds, velocity increases from 0 to 1 m/s, and from 2 to 4 seconds, it increases from 1 to 2 m/s.
Acceleration is the derivative of velocity with respect to time, so the slope gives acceleration.
If the slope is positive, acceleration is positive; if negative, acceleration is negative.
From 0 to 2 seconds, velocity is increasing, so acceleration is positive.
From 2 to 4 seconds, velocity is still increasing, so acceleration remains positive.
Acceleration is always positive, so no change in direction.
If the curvature is the same in both arcs, then the acceleration is in the same direction, which is positive.
Within 0 to 4 seconds, Car A's acceleration does not change direction.
